Staff Picks

Our staff pick their favourite titles. Read their reviews and reserve to collect from your library, or download to your device.

The Book Thief, by Markus Zusak.

Written by Tanya Collins · Published Dec 7, 2016

Enquiry officer Tanya Collins recommends The Book Thief, by Markus Zusak.

The Merchant of Venice: A Shakespeare Story by Andrew Matthews and Tony Ross

Written by Katie and Olivia Mitton · Published Dec 6, 2016

Young library customers Katie and Olivia really enjoyed this retelling of Shakespeare's Venetian play

The BFG

Written by Kate Bacon · Published Dec 6, 2016

Bookstart administator Kate Bacon recommends the film The BFG.

Room

Written by Nilima Banerji · Published Dec 5, 2016

Library and information advisor Nilima Banerji recommends the film Room

Elf

Written by Emma Yarrow · Published Dec 4, 2016

Elmswell Library manager Emma Yarrow recommends the film Elf.

Ten Little Elves, by Michael Brownlow & Simon Rickerty.

Written by Dawn Bamford · Published Dec 3, 2016

Kedington Library manager Dawn Bamford recommends Ten Little Elves, by Michael Brownlow & Simon Rickerty.

The Dinosaur That Pooped Christmas, by Tom Fletcher, Dougie Poynter & Garry Parsons

Written by Emma Maguire · Published Dec 2, 2016

Library and information advisor Emma Maguire recommends The Dinosaur That Pooped Christmas, by Tom Fletcher, Dougie Poynter & Garry Parsons.

The Zig Zag Girl by Elly Griffiths

Written by Bev Dann · Published Dec 1, 2016

Murder mystery The Zig Zag Girl offers interesting insights into life on the variety circuit in the 1950s

The Secret Diary of Hendrik Groen, 83 ¼, by Anonymous.

Written by Jo Dixon · Published Dec 1, 2016

Stock team member Jo Dixon recommends The Secret Diary of Hendrik Groen, 83 ¼, by an anonymous Dutch author.

The Sun King by Nancy Mitford

Written by Gill Mason · Published Nov 29, 2016

In The Sun King, Nancy Mitford describes Louis XIV's arts patronage, luxurious and extravagant lifestyle at Versailles, absolutist style of rule and colourful personal life.

Rose in the Blitz by Rebecca Stevens

Written by Emily Mitchell · Published Nov 24, 2016

Emily finds Rose in the Blitz cleverly mixes past and present, deals sensitively with the subject of dementia, and effectively delivers the message that love conquers all.

The Ever Never Handbook by Soman Chainani

Written by Emily Mitchell · Published Nov 10, 2016

The Ever Never Handbook provides an irreverent and imaginative take on fairytales.

Unboxed by Non Pratt

Written by Emily Mitchell · Published Oct 27, 2016

Emily finds Unboxed delicate, honest and poignant.

Fire Witch by Matt Ralphs

Written by Emily Mitchell · Published Oct 11, 2016

Emily reviews the second book in Matt Ralphs' Fire Girl series.

Raptor: A Journey Through Birds by James MacDonald Lockhart

Written by Helen Haynes · Published Sep 12, 2016

Helen reviews a hymn to the magnificent buzzards and kestrels of the British Isles.

Harry Potter and the Cursed Child by JK Rowling and J Thorne

Written by Helen Haynes · Published Sep 9, 2016

Helen reviews the latest in the Harry Potter series, a play combining the past and present.

I am China by Xiaolu Guo

Written by Alexandra Carter · Published Aug 23, 2016

Alexandra Carter from the Woodbridge Library Readers’ Circle reviews Xialou Guo's novel about a translator.

I am Bear by Ben Bailey Smith & Sav Akyuz

Written by Kate Ashton · Published Aug 16, 2016

Kate Ashton reviews a delightful picture book about Bear, who has purple hair

The Twilight Hour by Nicci Gerrard

Written by Gill Mason · Published Aug 9, 2016

Library and information advisor at Felixstowe, Gill Mason, reviews Nicci Gerrard's novel about a woman with a dark past.

Signs Preceding the End of the World by Yuri Herrera

Written by Richard Baker · Published Jul 26, 2016

Library and information advisor at Woodbridge, Richard Baker, reviews one of the Brave New Reads.

The Last Pilot by Benjamin Johncock

Written by Sophie Green · Published Jul 5, 2016

Woodbridge Library assistant manager Sophie Green reviews one of the Brave New Reads.

Only Ever Yours by Louise O’Neill

Written by Matt Shenton · Published Jul 5, 2016

Literacy ambassador Matt Shenton reviews dystopian novel Only Ever Yours.

Buffalo soldier by Tanya Landman

Written by Helen Scrivener · Published Jun 6, 2016

Woodbridge Library manager Helen Scrivener review a YA novel set in 19th century USA.

Mrs Hemingway by Naomi Wood

Written by Helen Scrivener · Published May 3, 2016

Woodbridge Library Manager Helen Scrivener reviews a book based on Ernest Hemingway's marriages.

Rosencrantz and Guildenstern are dead by Tom Stoppard

Written by Harriet Avery · Published Apr 18, 2016

Library and information advisor, Harriet Avery from Felixstowe Library, reviews this Hamlet-inspired play published in 1966 in honour of Felixstowe Library's 50th anniversary.

The magic finger by Roald Dahl

Written by Julie Wheeler · Published Apr 12, 2016

Julie Wheeler, library and information advisor at Felixstowe Library, reviews this Roald Dahl morality tale published in 1966, in honour of Felixstowe Library's 50th anniversary.

The signature of all things by Elizabeth Gilbert

Written by Helen Scrivener · Published Mar 30, 2016

Woodbridge Library manager Helen Scrivener reviews this sweeping saga.

Am I normal yet? by Holly Bourne

Written by Matt Shenton · Published Feb 8, 2016

Literacy ambassador Matt Shenton reviews a YA novel addressing OCD.

The wolf wilder by Katherine Rundell

Written by Debra Rowe · Published Jan 27, 2016

Debra Rowe, a Library and Information Advisor from Felixstowe Library reviews this wintery novel for young people.

Station eleven by Emily St. John Mandel

Written by Helen Scrivener · Published Jan 12, 2016

Woodbridge Library manager Helen Scrivener reviews Station eleven by Emily St. John Mandel.

A monster calls by Patrick Ness

Written by Kate Ashton · Published Dec 30, 2015

Haverhill Library assistant manager Kate Ashton reviews young adult novel, A monster calls.

Disclaimer by Renee Knight

Written by Amanda King · Published Dec 8, 2015

Amanda King, manager of Bungay Library reviews this thriller.

Uncle Montague’s tales of terror by Chris Priestley

Written by · Published Nov 24, 2015

Lakenheath Library manager Chris Howard reviews Uncle Montague’s tales of terror by Chris Priestley.

The kind worth killing by Peter Swanson

Written by Amanda King · Published Nov 4, 2015

Bungay Library manager Amanda King reviews a compelling thriller.

The Wickford Doom by Chris Priestley & Vladimir Stankovic

Written by Matt Shenton · Published Nov 4, 2015

A spooky Suffolk tale set during World War Two that will thrill and chill anyone who reads it.

Buffalo Soldier by Tanya Landman

Written by Matt Shenton · Published Nov 2, 2015

“What kind of a girl steals the clothes from a dead man’s back and runs off to join the army? A desperate one. That’s who.”

The Signalman by Charles Dickens"

Written by Matt Shenton · Published Oct 27, 2015

"Visited by an unnamed narrator, the signalman spends his days stuck in a dark, dank railway cutting that rarely sees light…"

George by Alex Gino

Written by Matt Shenton · Published Oct 26, 2015

A wonderful tale of an American transgender girl who dreams of playing Charlotte the spider in a school production of Charlotte’s Web.

The book of strange new things by Michel Faber

Written by Helen Scrivener · Published Oct 21, 2015

Woodbridge Library manager Helen Scrivener reviews The book of strange new things, a futuristic sci-fi novel.

11 books you need to read before you’re 21

Written by Henry Golding · Published Oct 7, 2015

Bury St Edmunds Library and information advisor Henry Golding recommends essential books for young adults to read.

Hear the wind sing and Pinball, 1973 by Haruki Murakami

Written by Matt Shenton · Published Sep 9, 2015

Literacy ambassador Matt Shenton reviews Hear the wind sing and Pinball, 1973 by Haruki Murakami - two newly translated stories from over 30 years ago.

Sawbones by Catherine Johnson

Written by Sophie Green · Published Aug 26, 2015

Woodbridge Library assistant manager Sophie Green reviews Sawbones, a historical thriller aimed at young teens.

The secret garden by F Hodgson Burnett

Written by Anna Hradsky · Published Jul 9, 2015

Library and information advisor Anna Hradsky talks about how her family loves this classic.

Jurassic Park by Michael Crichton

Written by Kate Ashton · Published Jun 22, 2015

Haverhill Library assistant manager Kate Ashton reviews Jurassic Park.

Blue Monday by Nicci French

Written by Charlotte Clark · Published Jun 18, 2015

Southwold Library manager Charlotte Clark reviews the thriller, Blue Monday by crime-writing couple Nicci French.

Sesame and spice by Anne Shooter

Written by Debra Rowe · Published Jun 18, 2015

Debra Rowe, a library and information advisor at Felixstowe Library, reviews Anne Shooter's exploration of international recipes.

We’re going to build a dam by Gillian McClure

Written by Debra Rowe · Published Jun 18, 2015

Debra Rowe, a library and information advisor at Felixstowe Library, reviews We’re going to build a dam, a beautifully illustrated picture book for young children.

The narrow road to the deep north by Richard Flanagan

Written by Helen Scrivener · Published Jun 18, 2015

Woodbridge Library manager Helen Scrivener reviews the 2014 Man Booker Prize winner, The narrow road to the deep north.

The quickening maze by Adam Foulds

Written by Helen Scrivener · Published Jun 18, 2015

Woodbridge Library manager Helen Scrivener reviews The quickening maze, a novel about the poets John Clare and Alfred Tennyson.
